text: Our entire frame is filled with the image of an American flag, stretched tight. We hear a jumble of conversation in the b.g.3; then:

{o.s.) At-ten-shun! Now we hear the click of hundreds of boots. GENERAL GEORGE S. PATTON, JR. steps into our view; more than six feet tall, he looms high against the b.g. of the flag. He glares down at us, the audience. A MILITARY BAND plays THE STAR SPANGLED BANNER, Patton comes to a smart salute, and we watch him for the dura- tion of the entire anthem. He is straight and husky and as gaudy as a peacock. His helmet is lacquered and shines with four silver stars. He wears a tailored tunic, with four stars on each shoulder, thirty brightly hued decorations on the left breast, five horizontal and three diagonal gold stripes on the sleeve. Beneath the tunic, he wears a shirt with four stars on each lapel, making a total of twenty stars. A vivid blue sash is draped across his breast, parallel to one of yellow, A red collar sash weighted by another medal hangs from his neck The rest of his costume consists of a gold-buckled belt, with his ivory-handled pistols on either side, riding breeches, boots, and a riding crop. Four stars on the handle of his pistols brings the grand total to twenty- eight stars. On his fingers he wears four conspicuous rings.

As the anthem continues, we cut to a series of tight shots featuring various aspects of Patton's uniform and decorations -- emphasizing the clusters of stars on his shoulders, his shirt, his pistols.  66
The anthem concludes and he completes his salute. Now this twenty-eight-star general scans us carefully. In & vibrant voice, and with a cold, mean look, he speaks directly at us:

At ease, men. I want you to remember that no bastard ever won a war by dying for his country, He won it by making the other poor dumb bastard die for his country... Men, the stuff we heard about America not wanting to fight, wanting to stay out of the war, was a lot of horsedung. Americans traditionally love to fight. All real Americans love the sting of battle. When you were kids you all admired the champion marble player, the fastest runner, the big league ballplayers, the toughest boxers. Americans love a . Winner and do not tolerate a loser. Americans play to win all the time. I wouldn't give a hoot in hell for a man who lost and laughed. That's why Americans have never lost, and will never lose a war, for the very thought of losing is hateful to Americans, An army is a team. It lives, sleeps, eats, fights as a team. This individu- ality stuff is a lot of crap. The bilious bastards who wrote that stuff about individuality for the Saturday Evening Post don't know any more about real battle than they do about a sock full of silt. We have the finest food, equipment, the best spirit and men in the world. Why, by God, I actually pity those poor bastards we're going against -- by God, I do, We won't just shoot the bastards. We're going to cut out their living guts and use them to grease the treads of our tanks. We're going to murder those lousy Hun bastards by the bushel. Many of you boys are wondering whether you'll chicken out under fire. Don't worry about it; I can assure you you will all do your duty. The Nazis are the enemy. Wade into them and spill their blood, Shoot them in the belly. When you stick your hand into a bunch of goo that a moment before was your best friend's face...you'li know what to Cont.

66 9 Cont. 10 PATTON (Cont. ) do. There's another thing I want you to remember. I don't want to get any messages saying: 'We are holding our position.' We're not holding anything. Let the Hun do that. We are advancing constantly and are not interested in holding anything, except onto the enemy. We're going to hold onto him by the nose and kick him in the ass. We'll kick the hell out of him all the time. We'll go through them like crap through a goose. pause) There's one thing you men will be able to say when you get home. You may all thank God for it, Thirty years from now, when you are sitting around the fireside with your grandson on your knee and he asks what you did in the great World War II, you won't have to say, 'I shoveled shit in Louvisiana.' (pause) All right -- now you sonsuvbitches kmow how I feel. I will be proud to lead you wonderful guys into battle anytime, anywhere He stares sincerely, almost wet-eyed at us for a moment.
That is all. —_—

We view the enormous sloping desert, baking hot in the midday sun. Tanks, half-tracks and self-propelled artillery are spread about in the distance. Scattered over the hot sands are the bodies of dead Americans, Arab women and children, dressed in brightly colored costumes, scavenge the uniforms, boots and equipment and pack them on heavily laden cameis.  a 5 66 il 12

One woman, an infant strapped to her back and a small child helping her, strips a soldier totally naked and hurries the precious belongings to the camel pack. The women work quickly and silently; there are no games, no joking, no playing with the treasure. We hear the sound of motor vehicles approaching.

Shimmering in the rising heat waves, two jeeps come into scene and pull up to a halt. In the rear are two American generals and, beside the Driver, a Captain who carries Cont.  12 Cont. 13 14 15 16 a submachine gun. The Major General carries a Springfield '03 rifle across his lap. In the other jeep is Bradley's Second Aide, who carries a bazooka. The Captain fires a burst of his submachine gun into the air to frighten off the Arab women, and they scurry toward their camels.
He shields his eyes from the sun as he rises to study the battlefield grimly. He is a tall, lanky, gentle-looking man. His face has great strength, but his eyes reflect wisdom and understanding.
(NOTE: Bradley will carry @ Springfield in Africa, a carbine in Sicily and a .45 in Europe.)
He is a man in his mid-twenties. He, too, is affected by the scene of carnage.
As the camera pans across the bitter scene, the Arab women melt into the arid folds of the desert.

Beside Bradley is BRIGADIER GENERAL CARVER. {Fictitious character -- no subtitle.) Since he participated in the debacle, he is diffident about commenting on it -- especially to a representative of General Eisenhower.
The Arabs need food and clothing. They strip our dead before we can even bury them. .
(studying the scene) Looks like the reports were accurate.

(consulting a pad) Sixty-one armored vehicles -- forty- five tons of ammunition -- twenty- five 40mm guns -- three self-propelled 105s. Not counting mortars, machine guns, rifles, pistols, telescopes, belt buckles, GI socks. Cont.  66 16 Cont. 17 18 19 20 CARVER (Cont. ) (uneasily) And one thousand eight hundred men. Bradley's gaze goes back to the silent battlefield.
Camera explores the stark horror of the silent, deserted killing ground.

The exotically caparisoned mounted Drummer filis the screen as he beats his two huge instruments with a flourish. Visually as well as auditorially, this is in sharpest contrast to the preceding scene. A military band of about one hundred pieces is blaring out a martial air. Camera pulls back to reveal the entire mounted band of a@ Moroccan regiment of Chasseurs-a-Cheval, with their sheep mascot and bell-covered umbrella. Lined up behind the band is the regiment, in scarlet uniforms, white capes and turbans.
The colorfully garbed SULTAN addresses General Patton, whose uniform and decorations are only slightly less bizarre than those about him.
My people salute you, General -- for your brilliant amphibious landing on the continent of Africa -- and for your enlightened administration of my country.

I've enjoyed being here, Your Excellency. But naturally I'd prefer to be up at the front in Tunisia fighting Germans. The Sultan nods, places the ribbon of a large disc-shaped decoration around Patton's neck,
(reading inscription) 'The lions in their dens tremble at his approach', Cont.  20 Cont. al 22 23 a4 25 26 Patton glances down, eyes the decoration.
(with genuine pride) I appreciate that, Your Excellency. There is a fanfare from the band and they turn to watch.
Playing a stirring march review, followed by the
» the band moves out to pass in colorful Chasseurs,

With Patton's party is LIEUTENANT COLONEL HENRY DAVENPORS (fictitious character -- no subtitle). At Patton's side is his Aide, CAPWAIN RICHARD N. JENSON. Patton is both fascinated and impressed by the color and the pageantry.
On the parade ground, a battalion of French territorial infantry in white uniforms passes in review, followed by Moroccan infantry with + are bristling with excit
The strutting commander battalion of Legionnaire red epaulets,

The Legion contingent is dressed units -- French with flowing capes. The man carries a huge knife suggest the romantic mil he red Fourragere, The streets ed spectators. of the Foreign Legion, leading a s in traditional white caps and iD followed by other exotically Senegalese, Goums on horseback y are fierce-looking and each - These French colonial troops itary splendor of the past.
Patton is clearly moved. This is his dish of tea. Cont,  26 Cont.
(fervently) Magnificent! (to Jenson) I wish our troops looked like that! He and the Sultan return the salute of the unit passing.
Tell me, General what do you think of Marrakech?
I love it, Your Excellency. It's a combination of Hollywood and the Bible.

Camera moves, with barbed wire fence in f.g., along the outside of the POW cage, picking up the faces of the American prisoners inside. They are a grim, bearded, dirty and dejected lot. Camera picks up an immaculate Africa Corps staff COLONEL striding along outside the wire carrying a briefcase. We follow him as he crosses to a command car in which is seated a German Field Marshal, surrounded by aides and staff officers.
ROMMEL, goggles on chest, is studying a map on which an officer is pointing out dispositions.
The staff Colonel comes into scene, presents himself to Rommel.
Heil Hitler! He gets no response from Rommel,

You wanted to see the interrogation reports on the American prisoners captured in our victory at Kasserine, Field Marshal. (he bands the briefcase to Rommel's aide) They are not very good soldiers, these Americans. Unimpressed, Rommel is incisive, thoughtful. He gives the Colonel a sharp giance. Cont.
I wouldn't be so sure after one battle. Their tanks were no match for our guns.
One could say the same, sir, for their leadership. Rommel eyes the Colonel evenly. He's not that easily flattered. .
They were not under American command at Kasserine. They were under British General Anderson -- did you know that?
(undaunted, he smiles) British commanders and American troops. They had the worst of everything!
I remind you that Montgomery is a British commander. And he has driven us halfway across Africa.
In any case, we have met the Americans for the first time and defeated them... Personally, I feel extremely optimistic. Rommel eyes him with dry disdain.
You can afford to be an optimist. I can't.

head_text.subj: EXT, U.S. II CORPS HEADQUARTERS, DJEBEL KOUIF TOWN SQUARE

text: The jeep bearing Bradley, Carver and Hansen drives up in front of the headquarters. Lounging dejectedly outside is a group of unkempt GIs, Bearded and unsoldierly, they Straggle to their feet, some managing a ragged salute. It is clearly e unit without discipline or morale, a unit that's suffered defeat. Bradley and Carver return the salutes as they step out of the jeep. Bradley studies the soldiers closely as the jeep pulls away and Hansen goes on inside.  66 28
(quietly, as he eyes the soldiers) These men fight at Kasserine?
(uneasily) Yes, sir. Bradley moves to go inside, changes his mind, turns to Carver, asking for frankness.
John, General Eisenhower sent me down here to make a report and I've got to lay it on the line. What went wrong?
Everything. Second-rate ta -- bad intelligence -- green troops... So green some of the boys marked our mine fields for their own protection and forgot to take the flags down.
(eyeing him shrewdly) Green commanders, too?
Yes, sir.

For the American Army to take a licking like that our first time at bat against the Germans -- (he shakes his head) Up against Rommel we need the best tank man we've got. Somebody tough enough to pull this outfit together.
(with a quick, apprehensive glance) George Patton?
(enigmatic) Possibly --
God help us.  66 29

We see the distant apparition of a chain of military vehicles kicking up the dust as it speeds along the desert, silhouetted before a great rising rosy sun. A siren wails, coming out of nowhere and growing louder and louder, until the half-track, with banners flying and machine guns fore and aft, comes at us as ostenta~ tiously as a fire engine.  66 30 31 32 33 34 35 36 10
General Patton, in a bulky trench coat, stands upright in the armored car, his face grimacing into the wind, a Caesar in his chariot.
The caravan roars into the decrepit square opposite the schoolhouse that serves as II Corps Headquarters. Arabs scurry through the streets in the midst of & cackling exodus of camels and chickens.

The caravan comes to a halt before the schoolhouse where a single SENTRY stands sloppily at his post. Patton steps over the side of his car, followed by a Lieutenant and a Captain. Patton regards the town square and the scruffy-looking soldiers lounging in it, his face frozen in the same expression as when it was blown by the wind. PATTON'S P.O.V. Groups of unshaven GIs, wearing sweaters and field Jacket yawning and indescribably slack, pyll themselves to their feet. Most of them manage a ragged series of salutes. Others simply watch with mild curiosity.
His jaw tightens, his eyes begin to flash.
They eye the General apprehensively. Jenson is a young man, STILLER in his mid-forties.

Eyes flashing, rage barely under control, he draws him- self up and snaps off an ultrasmart salute to the ragged crew, Turning on his heel, he passes a crudely built Sign designating II Corps Headquarters, on which a chicke squats. Nearby an Arab peddler leans, unimpressed, agains a pen of chickens.  —_ 37 38 39 66 12

The Sentry, without tie and needing a shave, pulls him- self to attention as Patton approaches. The man manages a salute, then stares at Patton with a sleck-jawed and not unfriendly smile. Patton's eyes widen. Incapable of speech, there issues from within. him a volcanic rumble that is almost a retch Failing to return the man's salute, he strides into the building.
Sentry, .where's the Duty Officer?
Sir, I don!t rightly know.
Is he in the building?
Sir, I'm under the impression he is not. Visibly irritated, Jenson goes on into the building, following Stiller.

Jenson follows Stiller down the corridor, which is quite dark because the blackout curtains have not yet been pulled open. Patton can be seen down the corridor, opening doors, glancing inside, slamming them shut again, He opens a map room door and steps inside, followed by Stiller.
Seated in the map room is a young SECOND’ LIEUTENANT, smiling contentedly, his feet up on a table, reading ae magazine. Seeing Patton and Stiller, he nervously hops to attention.
What are you doing, Lieutenant?
(flustered) Well, sir, I -- I'm on Map Room duty, sir,
That your map? Cont.  66 12 39 Cont. 4o 41
(tossing magazine aside No, sir -- it's definitely not amap, sir. Patton turns and strides out, followed by Stiller.

as Jenson enters. There are several desks in the make- shift office, at one of which sits a sleeping LIEUTENANT. A SERGEANT concentrates intently on a solitaire layout. Patton and Stiller appear in the corridor outside, pause to overhear the conversation.
The Lieutenant pops upright, pulls himself to his feet. The Sergeant merely looks up; he's seen a lot of captains
(sternly) Where's the Duty Officer?
Sir, he -- I think he's at his quarters, shaving.
Why isn't he here on duty?

I guess he needed a shave. (grinning) We've got a new commanding general due in today. Patton appears in the doorway, his face looking like a storm at sea. The Lieutenant instantly loses his grin. He hits a rigid attention, yells at the card-playing Sergeant.
(frenziedly) Forbes! Snap to! Patton turns on his heel with a growl of rage and disappe

He angrily moves down the dark corridor. We move faster and faster to keep up with him, until there is a dull clunk and Patton practically falls flat on his face. We hear a groan and then: Cont.  43 41 Cont. 42 43

Who the hell's kicking me in the butt! A PRIVATE, who had been curled asleep on the corridor flo rises, about to punch whomever it was in the nose, when h realizes that he is face to face with General Patton.
(coming to a salute) Oh! Sorry, sir.
What were you doing down there, soldier?
(decisively) Trying to get some sleep, sir. PATTON. Well, get the hell back down there, son. You're the only sonuvabitch in this headquarters who knows what he's trying to do!
Yessir.

Someone pulls aside heavy blackout curtains, letting in some light. SERGEANT WILLIAM GEORGE MEEKS, Patton's Negro orderly, and a coupie of other enlisted men carry the General's personal gear -- a footlocker marked with his name and rank, etc. -- up the stairs, Patton himself passes these bearers on his way upstairs, is met by Stiller as he reaches the second floor.

General Bradley's waiting in your office, sir. (pointing to an office) Down at the end of the hall. Patton and Stiller move off down the hall as, unseen by them, a couple of enlisted men carry by us a footlocker marked MAJOR GENERAL LLOYD R. FREDENDALL.

head_text.subj: INT, II CORPS COMMANDING GENERAL'S OFFICE

text: The spacious room is bare and depersonalized, having been just vacated. Bradley stands at a window, waiting. Cont.
} 43 Cont. (o.2.) PATTON'S VOICE O68. Brad! How the hell are you! Patton comes into scene and the two men shake hands.
Fine, George. Good to see you. (checking his watch) We were all under the impression that you wouldn't be here until 0900.
I gathered that. You lmow my boys, don't you? Dick Jenson and Al Stiller. Bradley nods with a smile.. Patton plants himself behind the desk, lights a cigar.

Tell me, Brad -- what are you doing here? a BRADLEY Ike wanted a report on this Kasserine setback. Meanwhile, I'm supposed to stay here in your headquarters -- as an observer -- but I report directly to Ike. His ‘eyes and ears' was the way he put it.
(grinning) I see - a spy! (turning to Jenson) Get me General Eisenhower's headquarters. Jenson picks up the phone.
(into phone) Allied Force Headquarters.
What really went wrong at Kasserine? I've only seen the preliminary report.

Apparently everything went wrong. We'd send over a 75mm shell, the Krauts would return an 68, Their tanks are diesels -- even when we managed to hit them they kept running. The men call our tanks 'Purple Heart Boxes.' One hot piece of shrapnel 66 and the gasoline explodes. ww Cont.  15 43 Cont.1
T warned them about the tanks.
I talked to one soldier about the half-tracks. Asked him if machine- gun fire pierced the armor. He said, 'No, sir -- the bullets only come in one side and rattle around a bit.!
I hear we had trouble coordinating the air cover.
The trouble was no air cover.
(handing him telephone ) General Smith on the line, sir.

(into phone) Beetle, I'm calling about Bradley and his job here... Look, I need @ good number two man. I want to make Brad my deputy commander... Okay? You clear it with Ike. He hangs up, takes a mean puff of his cigar, scowls up at Bradley shrewdly.
Now you're not spying for Ike anymore -- you're working for me. (challenging) Okay?
Fine. Patton turns to Jenson.
Dick -- you got those stars?
(with a grin) Yes, sir.

Well, let's get 'em on. Cont. 66  16 43 Cont.2 Jenson produces a handful of shiny three-star collar pieces. Patton sits down behind the big desk as Stiller on one side and Jenson on the other start to pin on the new insignia. An expression of doubt flashes across Bradley's face; Patton notices it.
Hell, I've been nominated by the President.
But it isn't official until it's approved by the Senate.
(grinning) Well -- they have their schedule end I have mine.

(watching the aides work) George, if you were named Admiral of the Turkish Navy, I'll bet your @ides could dip into their haversacks and come up with the appropriate badge of rank, . (with a grin) Anyway -- premature congratulations. Their ceremonial duties over, Stiller goes out and Jensén busies himself arranging a desk for himself. Patton rises and crosses to a mirror to inspect his new rank. Bradley crosses to the window.

Those stars would look a lot better on a green shirt... Did I ever tell you I once designed a uniform for tank crewmen? It was green leather with red stripes, sort of a row of brass buttons here and topped by a gold football helmet. (wistfully) The Army rejected it. But damn, it was beautiful. Camera moves in on Bradley at the window, looking down into the street below. Ane our . 45 ~—  46 47 4g. 50 51 17 BRADLEY'S P.0.V. GENERAL FREDENDALL, in a jeep with a driver and one aide, is saying good-bye to a couple of his staff officers. It is obviously a dispirited and uncomfortable farewell.
Bradley indicates the street below to explain what he's been looking at.
Lloyd Fredendall's just leaving. Patton crosses to the window. out
Fredendall's jeep barrels out of the square and disappear Camera pans to Patton's command car, where two drivers ar replacing a huge two-star plate with a huge three-star plate.
Bradley and Patton are still watching down below. Bradley turns to Patton.
George, there's one other thing I put in my Kasserine report. Some of our boys were just plain scared.

They'1l get over that. Even the best foxhounds are gun-shy the first time out. I can remember when nothing scared me worse than the idea of a bullet coming straight for my nose. I don't know why, but somehow the idea of getting it straight in the nose was just more horrible than any other possibility.
(a wry smile) I can understand that, George, with such a handsome nose. Cont.  wy 66 52 Cont. 18

(relighting his cigar; he pulls on it fiercely) You want to know why this outfit got the hell kicked out of it? A blind man could see it in five minutes! They don't look like soldiers -- they don't act like soldiers -- why should they fight like soldiers?!
No question about it -- the discipline's pretty poor.

(looking at his watch) Starting in fifteen minutes, we're going to turn these boys into razor- sharp fanatics. (Vesuvius preparing to erupt) . These men may lose their fear of Germans, but by God they'11 never lose their fear of me!
Patton and Jenson cross the square on their way to the officers' mess hall.
A few sleepy OFFICERS have begun to straggle in as Patton enters, with Jenson in tow. A cheerful COOK approaches.
Up bright and early, General. Breakfast?
Am I to understand that my officers have all finished their breakfast? cook We're open from six to eight. Most of the officers are just coming in, sir.
(indicating officers entering) Inform these officers that the mess hall is closed. Cont.  66 19 54 Cont. 55 56 cook But, sir, it's only a quarter to eight.
After this, you open at six o'clock and no one is admitted after six- fifteen...Where are your leggings? cook (startled) Leggings? Hell, General, sir, I'm a cook.
You're a soldier! (over his shoulder, to Jenson) A twenty dollar fine. Scowling, Patton turns away from the flabbergasted Cook to the others present.
You all heard me. Beginning now, men without leggings or helmets or ties - men with unshined shoes and soiled uniforms -- are going to get skinned for it!
Panning with them as they move away, Patton growling to ~ Jenson quietly.
Hit ‘em in the pocketbook and they'll remember.

This is a large room that's been converted into enlisted men's quarters, with rows of bunks, combat gear, etc. As Patton, accompanied by Jenson, sweeps through the empty room, his eye falls on a pinup tacked to the wall. We get a glimpse of a raw, provocative pose of an enormously bosomed girl. Patton pauses, his Puritan outrage unmistakable.
This is a barracks -- not a bordello! He tears the picture off the wall, balls it up and throws it down sternly. Then he marches out,

Camera follows Patton in f.g. as, in going from squad room to town square, he happens to pass a row of canvas stalls, followed by Jenson, Seated in each stall is a soldier, revealed from the neck up. Patton speaks curtly as he passes the first stall. The soldier inside is hat- less.

No helmet -- twenty dollars. {passing tha second stall) No helmet and no leggings -- twenty-five dollars. He crosses to the third stall where a very young and sharply turned-out GI sits at attention, a polished helmet on his head. He looks straight ahead, but his face wears a vacuous and slightly pained expression appropriate to what he's doing.
Now that man looks like a soldier!
Patton and Jenson cross the square to the building being used for a hospital. They are trailed by wide-ayed urchins.

I do not admit the existence of ‘battle fatigue.' Once you concede its reality, you admit the reality of demoralization. And you can't win battles with demoralized troops. That sort of thing has to be stopped or you get ean uncontrollable infection... Like conscientious objection.
Patton, followed by Jenson, moves down the aisle of the busy ward, where he is met by a MEDICAL OFFICER. Nurses and other medical personnel (except this medical officer} all wear helmets.
(he's got a head of steam up) I understand you have two cases of self-inflicted wounds.
Yes, sir -- we do. Cont.
66 58 cont.
Get them out of here.
Sir, one of them's developed a serious infection.
I don't give a damn if he croaks. Get him somewhere else, but out of here. They don't belong in the same Building as boys who've been wounded in battle.
{acceding without agreeing I'll see that they're moved, sir.
Another thing -- there'll be no "battle fatigue’ in my command... That's an order!
Yes, sir.
(growling contemptuously) Battle fatigue is a free ride; a little yellow-belly's ticket to a hospital... I'm not going to subsidize cowardice.
(eyeing the General blandly) Yes, sir -- Patton has started to turn away, but something in the doctor's tone pulls him back.
Where's your helmet, Doctor?
I don't .wear a helmet when I'm in the hospital, General.
{turning to leave) Start. Cont.  (a) Se 66 22 58 cCont.1 59 60
(after Patton) I can't use my stethoscope when I'm wearing my helmet...
(realizes he's been challenged ) Then cut two holes in your helmet so you can. AND GET THOSE YELLOW- BELLIES OUT OF HERE TODAY.

A two-and-a-half-ton truck is parked out on the desert beside the dusty, deserted road. There is nothing else to be seen for miles. Camera moves in on truck, coming to rest as it reveals a SERGEANT reclining in the cab, smoking while he watches a PFC standing beside the cab shaving. The soldier's tin mirror and helmet full of water rest on the hood of the truck.
You know what's so important in the back of this truck? Preoccupied with shaving, the Pfc shakes his head.
. Shoe polish.
Shoe polish?!

Georgie Patton is a nut about spit and polish. If I let you turn up at his headquarters without a shave, you'd get a month in the stockade. There is the sound cf an approaching vehicle, then the insistent honking of a horn. The Sergeant, irritated, sticks his hand out of the cab, without looking, and motions the other vehicle ahead.
(impatiently) Come ahead, you silly bastard!

Revealing a jeep as it drives up alongside the soldier shaving. Beside the SERGEANT DRIVER (Bradley's driver) the jeep contains a three-star and a two-star general -- Cont.  23 60 Cont. Patton and Bradley. The shaving soldier gulps, faced suddenly with all that brass. He shifts his razor awkwardly, manages a salute.
frowning sternly) What's in that helmet, soldier?
Water, sir -- (helplessly indicating Sergeant) He told me to shave.
need I want your head in that helmet -- not water! With the back of his hand, Patton sweeps the helmet off the hood of the truck.

oO Now pick it up and wear it! As the PFC retrieves his helmet, Patton gestures to his driver and the jeep roars on out of scene. The PFC is. stunned by this general who materializes out in the deser and disappears in a matter of seconds.
(to Sergeant) You told me he wanted everybody to shave.
I also told you he was a nut!
Patton is studying the terrain ahead.
Turn right here, driver.
Sir, the battlefield is straight ahead.
Don't talk back to me, Sergeant. y I can smell a battlefield.
(quietly) George, he was out here just yesterday. BS Cont.  24 OC) 61 Cont. 62 63 64 65 66
(insistently) It's over there. Turn right, dammit! The Driver makes the turn as ordered.

as the jeep approaches from the distance. -Camera moves along the silent eternal ruins of what was once an aqueduct. The car comes to & stop, Patton, dwarfed by the structure, steps out and looks up at the ancient ruin in awe. The wind makes an eerie sound through the stone.
Bradley steps out of the car, moves closer to Patton.

(quietly) It was here. The battlefield was here. (pause) The Carthaginians defending the Aqueduct were attacked by three Roman legions. The Carthaginians were proud and brave, but they couldn't hold, Massacre. Arab women stripped them of their tunics, their swords, their lances. The soldiers lay naked in the sun...
listening, puzzled, as the strange wind whistles.
(o.s.) .-.two thousand years ago.
I was there, Brad. (with a faint smile) You don't believe me, do you? Bradley doesn't react.

You know what the poet said -- Cont,  66 65 Cont. 25 PATTON (Cont.) (quoting -- and giving it every- thing) 'Through the travail of ages, Midst the pomp and toils of war, Have I fought and strove and perished countless times upon the star.
as he listens, studying Patton. 67 TwO SHOT
(o.s.) So as through a glass and darkly The age~-long strife I see
Where I fought in many guises, Many names -- but always me.' (after a suitable pause for effect) You know who the poet was?
No.
(with a sudden grin) Me.

Patton has had the. map room totally revamped and it is now an elaborate and buzzing center of charts and information. COLONEL GASTON BELL (fictitious character - no subtitle), is conducting a briefing for Patton, Bradle Jenson, Stiller, Hansen and several other OFFICERS, using a map.

There's an opportunity here for us to mount an cffensive. We have concentrated on harassing the enemy's flank, to draw his strength away from the British. However, it appears now that we could split the Africa Corps and drive through Rommel to the sea.  66 70 ah 26
(sardonically) Sorry, Bell -- that territory is reserved for General Sir Bernard Law Montgomery. We're supposed to let him win this one -- (sarcastically) -- no matter how long it takes him to do it.
They're entitled to have their hero. After all, Montgomery pushed Rommel clear across North Africa.
What about the Americans? They need a hero, too, don't they?
(with a quiet smile) You have anybody in mind, George? Jenson énters.
Excuse me, sir, Air Vice Marshal Coningham is here with General Buford. Patton rises, dismissing them with a nod.

The huge vehicle waddles forward off the ramp, dropping into the surf that covers its tracks. However, it survive and moves up the beach.

Carver, Davenport, Bell, Codman and several other officer are watching and grinning as "the old man" demonstretes the new equipment successfully. A staff car drives up and the staff salutes snappily as General Alexander steps out
The huge vehicle has stopped at the water line, and Patto jumps down out of the turret as Codman comes into scene.
(exuberantly) It works, Codman, it works! With that snorkel equipment, we can land any place!
General Alexander is here, sir -- Patton turns, moves off toward staff car.  66 174 54
Patton comes into scene and salutes as Alexander gets out of the car. Alexander returns the salute, then the two men shake hands.
(full of enthusiasm) Sir Harold, congratulations on a great British invention. If it weren't so damn secret I'd like to call in the photographers.
George, I have bad news for you about your Sicily plan. I'm afraid Ike has turned it down. Patton is both amazed and annoyed.
He feels that since the Italians will be defending their native soil for the first time, and since German resistance is stiffening, our forces shouldn't be divided.
Where do I land then?
in the Gulf of Gele.
What for? There's nothing there but a beach.
Yes, but it puts you in good position to support Montgomery.
(evenly) And where does Montgomery land?
He'll land in Syracuse and drive north to Catania -- possibly even Messina. You'll be alongside, protecting his left.
(bitterly) You mean we get the burden again, while good old Monty gets the glory. Cont.  55 174 Cont. 175
Ike had to consider all points of view. He made his decision not as an American but as an ally. (after a moment) If it were the other way ‘round, I assure you Monty would protest.

No, dammit, I've been in the Army thirty years, and when I get an order, I say ‘Yes, sir', and do my damndest to carry it out. (unable to contain his fury, he growls) But this is what you get when your commander-in-chief stops being an American and becomes an ally.

On a screen in the darkened room we see projected in black and white (and without sound) uncut U.S. Signal Corps footage of Patton landing on the beach at Gela. Harkins and other staff officers are with him. In some of the shots Signal Corps cameramen appear with their hand-held Eyemos. Patton steps off a landing craft and wades ashore with his fiercest expression, pistols on his hips, shiny helmet gleaming, surrounded by his staff. Since this is uncut footage, we see the Signal Corps slate -- PATTON - SICILY LANDING - ROLL 3. There follows other angles of the same action, revealing that this is staged for the cameras with Patton's willing - if not eager - cooperation. We even see him put on his fierce warlike scowl the moment the cameras roll. During the above, the following is heard from o.s.:
(9.s8.) Here is the gangster Patton arriving on the beach at Gela with his Seventh Army.

(o.s.) This film was captured after the ianding. Camera pulls back and we recognize the map room in which are seated several Wehrmacht officers in addition to Jodl and Steiger. The room, of course, is in color, the film Cont.  56 175 Cont. on the screen being the only thing in black and white. The Army footage continues, showing action shots of troop going ashore and other aspects of the amphibious landing. The German officers continue their conversation as they watch shots of Patton on the beach yelling orders at individual soldiers, cursing them as he urges them inland
I didn't realize he was so tall.
Over six feet.
He is constantly giving personal commands.

Obviously they now have two prima donnas in Sicily -- Montgomery and Patton, On the screen there appears a shot of Bradley landing with his troops on another beach. Wearing ordinary GI uniform except for the stars on his helmet, he steps into the surf with a few of his staff, carrying a carbine and almost indistinguishable from the soldiers landing with him. The whole tone is as unpretentious and businesslike as Petton was flamboyant.
There's another three-star general. Who is he?
This is General Bradley. He commands the American Second Corps.
He looks like a common soldier.
He is extremely capable and completely unpretentious. Most unusual for a general. {he turns to find Jodl glaring at him; quickly) I beg your pardon, sir.
Bradley's jeep moves down road toward Patton's command post in b.g.  57 177 aes PATTON'S COMMAND POST - A FARMHOUSE IN SOUTHERN
Patton, Bell and Codman are in the elaborate but portable map room. Bell is at a map of Sicily.
I don't think I've made myself clear, sir. It's true that Montgomery has met the toughest resistance of the campaign here at Catania. However --
(secretly enjoying himself) It's perfectly clear. Monty's as stuck as a bug on flypaper.
‘(indicating paper in bis hand) . But this order from General Alexander... he's directing you to give up the Vizzini-Caltagirone Road and turn it over to Montgomery!
(shrugging) So Bradley will have to fight his way up the center over tough mountain roads -- that's all. a BELL (eyeing Patton uncertainly) Yes, sir --

(nudging Bell, he taps the map at Messina) : Here's where the ball game is, Bell -- up here at Messina. If they'd used my plan, I'd have been there by this time and cut off the escape of every damn Kraut and Italian on this island... But I'll tell you what I'm going to do now. I'm going to Palermo first, then I'm going to beat that Limey into Messina! Bradley enters,.his face grim, something obviously on his mind. Cont. 66  66 177 Cont. 58
George -- what's this about taking the Vizzini Road away from Second Corps?
General Alexander's orders. He says the road goes to Montgomery.
That road was assigned to me. How am I going to move north without it? You know the terrain up there.
(his heart bleeding) I know, Brad, but Monty's run into tough opposition -- very tough. Bradley glances at the map, then eyes Patton with growing suspicion.
George -- you wouldn't be taking advantage of this situation, would you?
I don't know what you're talking about.
Without that road, all of your army but my Second Corps is out of a job. Free to go on to Palermo, if you like.
Who said anything about Palermo?
I can read a map. (indicating probing salients on map) Does Alexander know you've pushed out this far?
(waving this aside) Hell, that's nothing but a reconnaissance in force.

(firmly accusing) George, are you telling me I've got to slug it out over those mountains with heavy resistance just so you can make a bigger splash than Monty? Cont.  59 177 Cont.1 ‘@) PATTON (full of helpless innocence) Brad, I just carry out my orders, like the simple old soldier I am. Carver enters with a teletype dispatch in his hand. He nods respectfully to Bradley.
General Bradley -- (to Patton) Sir, General Alexander's gotten wind of your westerly movement. He says here: 'Stop immediately. Go no farther than Agrigento. Repeat, stop immediately.'

(eyeing Carver for a moment) That's what you think it says. But I think it was garbled in transmission. Ask them to re- transmit the message -- and take your time about it. @ (with a wink at Bradley) That'll take half a day at least.
Yes, sir. He goes.
Where were we, Brad?

(slowly, accusingly, his eyes fixed on Patton) We were talking about e simple ald soldier... 178 EXT. ROAD TO PALERMO - LONG SHOT - DaY Columns of Patton's tanks and self-propelled artillery sp along the primitive Sicilian road. There is no resistance ag the tanks barrel along with hatches open and infantry- men on top. 66  66 179 180 181 182 183 60
Patton's armored command car, along with the rest of his entourage, races past a column of two-and-a-half-ton trucks, its siren blasting. A line of Italian prisoners is being herded to the rear.
Standing up in the command vehicle, Patton views the scen of speeding, clanking, irresistible power with undisguise exultation.
(rapturously ) Look, Cod. Could anything be more magnificent?!... I must tell the truth -- I love it. Goddammit, I do love it! Codman glances at him, not quite sure how to respond.

Bradley's jeep, in which are Bradley, his driver, Hansen and Bradley's Second Aide, drives along a road by a farm- house held by an American infantry platoon, From a hillside nearby, German artillery is pounding the area.
As the jeep approaches the farmhouse, the shelling grows more intense. A shell hits too close for comfort and, at a signal from Bradley, all four men bail out.

Bradley and his party take cover. As a shell hits nearby, a GI from the infantry platoon also dives for cover behin the wall. There is another tremendous explosion and debris rains down on the men huddled behind the wall. The GI pulls himseif up, unable to see from his position the insignia worn by the others.
(disgustedly) Wonder what silly sonuvabitch is in charge of this operation!
(with a wry, private grin) I don't know, but they ought to hang him.  66 184 185 186 61
A British Colonel stands before the desk of Montgomery, who refers sternly to a piece of paper in his hand.

I want this communique entirely rewritten. British armies are never "bogged down by enemy resistance’. We ‘momentarily slow our advance to prepare for new and stunning blows against the enemy'. (scathingly) If you're going to write, Welkin, for God's sake use a little imagination!

Patton's cavalcade storms up to the headquarters and pull to a halt. Out in front, as Patton steps down from his command car, is a group of four or five clergymen, in clerical collars, being escorted by the Seventh Army CHAPLAIN. Patton greets him in high good humor.
‘Afternoon, Chaplain --
General, these gentlemen are here from the States looking over our program for the spiritual welfare of the men.
Good. Stick with us and we'll take you into Palermo.
(indicating Chaplain) Colonel Davis showed us your quarters, General Patton, and I was interested to see a Bible beside your bed. Do you actually find time to read 1%?
Ga dead earnest) I sure do... Every goddamn day.
Steiger approaches Jodl, who is studying a wall map of the Russian front.
Sir -- the Americans have taken Palermo!
Damn!  ©
Montgomery sits at a table, dressed in his roguish, casua Manner, as an AIDE enters.
General -- Patton's taken Palermo!
(explosively) Damn!
Camera moves up the inclined road, whizzing past crowds o Sicilians chanting in a definite rhythm: "Viva, viva, viv viva.
Two command cars and two jeeps. With Patton are Codman an Davenport.

(enjoying himself enormously) Palermo is the most conquered city in the world. The Phoenicians, the Carthaginians, the Romans, the Byzantines. Then came the Arabs, the Speniards, the Neapolitans. And now me.

Patton's vehicles press through the cheering crowd as peo offer lemons and watermelons to the victorious Americans. A motorcycle courier makes his way through the crowd, draws up alongside the command car. He holds out a messag which Codman reaches over and takes from his hand. TwO SHOT - PATTON AND CODMAN Codman has glanced at the message.
(with a grin) This is from General Alexander, sir, reminding you that you are not to take Palermo.

Send him a message, Codman. Ask him if hs wants me to give it back.  66 192 193 ao Ae MeD. LONG SHOT The Patton convoy comes to a halt in front of a cathedral at the entrance to which stands a Cardinal in all his fin Leaving the car, Patton strides over and kisses the Cardi ring, a gesture which is theatrically perfect and brings a ringing cheer from the people lining the sidewalk. EXT. PATTON'S PALAZZO IN PALERMO ~ FULL VIEW - DaY At each of the four corners of the palace a tank, fully manned, stands guard. Patton is conducting a press conference on the lawn. He stands like a conquering king, wearing a custom-tailored whipcord jacket. CORRESPONDENTS sit about the lawn on folding chairs.
{ebullientiy) For a change, let me ask you a question. You've just come from Washington. What's the reaction to our boys taking Palermo?
(hesitantly) Well, sir -- the general impression is that your Seventh Army berreled through token resistance, while Montgomery faced the brunt of the fighting.
(his smile hits the ground like a sack of lemons) By God, don't they know we took on the Eerman Goering Division, the toughest outfit in the German army?
The people back home are interested in you, General. They're curious about your peari-handled revolvers.
(outraged) They're ivory! Wobody but a pimp for a cheap New Orleans whorehouse would carry a pearl-handled pistol!
What about your languege, Generel? Cont.
193 Cont. 6h
When I want something to stick, I give it to them loud and dirty so they'll remember it.
How do the men react to that?
God dammnit, I don't want these men to love me -- I want them to fight Tor me! (eyes flashing, jaw set)
Ernie Pyle says you've got a secret weapon here in Sicily -- General Bradley. ‘The GI General' -- that's what Ernie calls him.
(gruffly) Omer Bradley's no secret. He's a damn fine commander.
Whet's your feeling about Montgomery?
He's the best generel the Limeys have. But he's more concerned about not losing a battle than he is about winning one.
(baiting him) You think he's not aggressive enough -- is that correct? Patton notices the men have been scribbling furiously, starts to pull back. Cont.
a, 193 Cont.1

Now, wait a minute, boys -- I've been getting into enough trouble lately. Yesterday the Inspector General's office told me my Italian prisoners didn't have enough latrines. They never knew what a goddamn latrine was until I showed them! (this gets a laugh) So if anything I've said sounded critical of my distinguished British colleague -- I hope you'll just forget it. (again unable to resist, he smiles) I will tell you this, off the record. I'm going to beat the sonuvabitch into Messina!
The headline reads: PATTON VOWS TO TAKE MESSINA,
Camera pulls back to reveal the newspaper is in Montgomery's hand. Monty is building up a head of steam as he reads. MAJOR GENERAL DE GUINGAND enters with a report in his hand.
Cont.
a, 194 Cont. 65
(outraged) Freddy, do you realize what this madman Patton is seying? He's going to save our skins by taking Messina}
You might find this report interesting, sir. :

(his smoldering jealousy building) Here I am in these bloody marshes, fighting malaria as well as Germans,,. while he's taking Palermo without opposition and getting all the glory. (having glanced at report, elatedly) Well! Now he's up against three good Jerry divisions and he's stuck for a change... He's not going to get Messina. That's reserved for the British Eighth Army and me!
They are walking through an olive grove toward the head- quarters, Both men appear concerned, preoccupied, ARTILLERY FIRE can be heard in the distance.
It's very simple, Lucian. Terry Allen's bogged down east of Troina. Youtre bogged down on the coast road. We need an end run here to break things loose.
Patton has appeared at the doorway of the farmhouse. Cont.  66 197 Cont. 66

Gentlemen, do you realize where we are? We're'in an olive grove where Hannibal may have wandered. (warmly) Lucian! How's my little fighting sonuvabitch? (motioning them inside) Come on in. Brad and I have a job for you. We tried the same thing last week and picked up twelve miles. Everybody from old man Churchill on down was waving our flag.
Patton crosses to map, jabs with his cigar, describing en arc around the Germen defenses on coast road.
Lucian -- we want you to senda reinforced battalion by sea to make @ landing up hsre behind the Kraut lines. Last week we brought in sixteen hundred prisoners that way.
General Bradley says you want me to tie this in with a land-based attack.
That's right... I want a coordinated assault the morning of the eleventh.
I don't think we can make the linkup by the eleventh.
Hell, it's only fifteen or twenty miles!
General, my boys have been fighting and dying for yards.
Maybe you better Kick a few butts if you have to. (a warm personal appeal) Lucian -+ I recommended you for your DSM end your last promotion. JI know what you can do if you put your mind to it. Cont.
I'm sorry -- I can't do the impossible!
Dammnit, Lucian, you're too old an athlete to think you can postpone a match that's been scheduled.
You're an old athlete yourself, sir. You know that matches sometimes are postponed.
George -- if Lucian's right and we can't back it up by land, our end run could ‘be a disaster. Those men might get caught up there on the beach and cut to pieces.
(thoroughly annoyed) What's the matter with you two?
All we're talking about is not rushing in before we're ready... Give him an extra day.
Just one more day --
(angrily) I will like heli! The landing is on. We're going to Messina and we're going to get there before Monty does.
What's so important about that? Infuriated by this challenge to his own indefensible position, Patton seethes.
Truscott, if your conscience won't let you conduct this operation, I will relieve you and let someone else do it. Cont.
os oO. 68 198 Cont.2
General, it's your privilege to relieve me anytime you want to. There is a long moment, during which Patton gets his ange under control. He speaks with absolute authority.
Gentlemen, this match will not be postponed. (to Truscott) You got any questions?
No, sir. Patton breaks the tension by setting out three glasses from a tray on his desk and reaching for the decanter.

(as he pours three drinks) Llucian -- you're a good man, but you're too damn conservative... You know what Frederick the Great said? Always audacity! 'Ltaudace, l'audace, toujovrs l'audace!! (shoving *® glass toward Truscott) Come on -- let's have a drink. Unwilling to bend the knee, Truscott speaks with quiet dignity.
Excuse me, sir -- I'm not going to be drinking the next couple of days. He salutes, turns and goes out. Patton glances over to find Bradley's eyes staring at him evenly.
Ceorge, if anything happens to those men, I want to be with them.
Well, you're not going -~- so forget it. (belligerently resentful) What are you trying to tell me -- that Truscott's right? Cont.  © 66 69 198 Cont.2 199 200 201- 20h, 205 206

(his sense of outrage taking over) You're gambling with the lives of those boys just so you can beat Montgomery into Messina. If you pull it off, you're a hero. But if you don't, what about them? Think about the ordinary combat soldier, He doesn't share your dreams of glory. He's stuck here -- living out every day with death tugging at his elbow. {his bitter anger growing) There's one big difference betwean you and me, George. I do this job because I'm trained to do it. You do it because you love it! Bradley turns and walks out, leaving Patton staring afte> hin.

location: GROUP OF LANDING CRAFT OFF SHORE

text: Combat-equipped infantrymen are huddled in the dark landing craft, torn as always between hope and fear.

A. The landing craft let down their ramps with a huge splash. B. They disgorge their cargo of assault troops. C. The infantrymen make e silent and unopposed dash across the sand to an embankment beside the coast road.
From far down the road the sound of an approaching ENGIN: is heard. In a momens we can see a motorcycle with side- car, then we recognize the rider as a Cerman soldier.
In the dark, the word is passed in a whisper from one rifleman to the next, eamera following as each man receives and passes on the message: Cont,  70 206 Cont. 207 208 209 210- 211 212- 214 215 66
Hold your fire. This is repeated in turn by two or three succeeding riflemen.

The silence is shattered by the sharp clatter of the moto eycle's engine. Shooting down the line of riflemen, we can see their heads turn as the word to hold fire is passed toward camera. But a soldier in f.g. who has not yet got the word, sees the approaching German cyclist. He raises his rifle and fires.
as the German cyclist is hit. He screams and his motor- eycle slews wildly off the road, depositing his twisted body in a ditch.

Shooting over the riflemen taking cover behind it. There is a sudden, startling flash of light as a parachute flar illuminates the area. Then, from the wooded rise across the road, all hell breaks loose. Machine guns, mortars and small arms fire suddenly comes pouring onto the beach
German machine guns and mortars firing.

The American Infantrymen take what cover they can egainst the enbankment, but the mortar shells lob in as they find the range. A. Infantryman getting hit. B. Landing craft shoving off beach under heavy mortar fir C, Riflemen who have scrambled to the top of the enbank- ment to fire are cut down by machine gun bursts. INT, PATTON'S HEADQUARTERS aT FORWARD COMMAND POST -
Carver is on a field phone and Patton is pacing the floor his face a storm cloud of frustration. Cont.  C) 215 Cont. 216 217 218 219 66 72
(holding the phone) Those men on the beach are really catching hell, General. Truscott's men are doing their best, but we have no replacements for him and he cantt break through to the coast.
(with sudden grim decision) I'm going up there myself.
A column of tanks is halted beside the river. The COLONEL in command, his helmet off, is fuming over a map with a couple of staff officers.
(o.s., roaring as from a distance) Colonel -- ! The Colonel looks up, stares across the river in amazemen
How the hell did he get over there?
standing on the opposite bank, yelling.
What the hell are you waiting for?!
Looking for a place to ford, General. I sent out a patrol to reconnoiter.
I've already done that. Down by those trees this sewer's only three feet deep. (lashing out) You get that outfit cranked up or you're going so be out of a job!  66 220 221 222 223 72
(quaking) Yes, sirl
(roaring) And put that helmet on! Fumbiing for his helmet, the Colonel hastens to comply.
An infantry platoon rises up from positions of cover and moves forward. Almost immediately they are taken under heavy machine-gun fire.

location: BATTALION COMMAND POST, (A BOMB-DAMAGED PEASANT HUT)

text: DaY In the tiny room there are Patton and Stiller; a shattere LISUTENANT COLONEL, who is battalion commander; a Major, who is his executive; and a communications SERGEANT. Patton is taking the hide off the Lieutenant Colonel, who is trying to defend himself.
The reason we're pinned down, General, is we can't get any air support.

The hell with that! Nobody's getting air support! (raging) If you can't put some fire under this battalion, Colonel, by God we'll find somebody who can! (jabbing a forefinger at the Major) I'm putting you in command, Major! (fiercely) I'll give you four hours -- and if you don't break through to that beachhead, I'll fire youl Patton turns and stalks out, followed by Stiller.
Colonel, there are fifty thousand men on this island who'd like to shoot that sonuvabitch.

head_text.subj: OUTSKIRTS SMALL TOWN IN CENTRAL SICILY

text: A mechanized artillery outfit -- guns, trucks, weapons, etc. -- is stalled and bunched up on the road leading Cont.

66 73 223 Cont. 22k 225 226 227 into the little town, making a perfect target for air attack. Patton's command car barrels into scene and he is livid when he sees the vulnerable column of motionless equipment. He yells to a SERGEANT in a weapons carrier.
(roaring) what's holding up this column?

(appalled when he recognizes the apoplectic face of Patton) I -- I don't know, sir -- From o.s. there is the sound of approaching aircraft. Patton glances up, then gives his driver a poke in the back. —

Let's go. The driver pulls the car off onto the shoulder of the roa and roars ahead, steeving an expert but dangerous course between the stalled colvmn and the steep ditch beside th: road. The roar of the planes is almost overhead now.
The German planes open up with their machine guns.
as the planes strafe the entire length of the sitting duck column, Men scatter and some are cut down. Patton's command car continues to skirt the edge of the road at top speed,
Machine-gun fire spatters all around it. The driver duc‘c down as best he can. Codman and the others are on the floor. But Patton is still standing, his jaw jutting in angry defiance.
(his voice cool) Pull up over there.
This is a narrow bridge leading into the tiny town. On the bridge we see what is holding up the column. A cont.

66 ans 227 Cont. 228 229 230 231 232 SICILIAN PEASANT, alternately crying and shouting, is trying to coax a team of donkeys attached to his cart to move off the bridge so the machinery of war can get acros An exasperated MAJOR, along with a couple of noncoms, tri to aid in moving the donkeys. Suddenly Patton is upon them.
What the hell's going on here?
Sir, it's these mules --

(furious) They're jackasses}! You let a whole column get stalled and strafed on account of a couple of jackasses? What the hell's the matter with you? Before the Sicilian has time to do more than cry out in protest, Patton has drawn his pistol.
He fires twice, There is a scream of anguish from the Sicilian.
The donkeys now lie motionless on the bridge.
(to the Major and his men) Don't just stand there! Dump them in the river! The men move to obey, pushing the heavy corpses over the side.
as the beasts hit the river. We see in the reflection that the column is moving again.
They bank into a steep turn to come back for another pass at the helpless column,
The machine euns clatter as they go into their second strafing run.  66 233 23k 235 236 237 238 75

The column is gathering speed as it clatters across the bridge. The planes roar over, but the moving equipment is harder to hit. Patton stands alone at the side of the bridge, oblivious to the machine-gun fire stitching the area around him, impatiently waving the vehicles across and urging them to greater speed.

On the bright sunlit road Patton's vehicles, returning from the front, have slowed to avoid a truck convoy heade toward the front. On the other side of the road, headed back, is a straggling line of GIs, the walking wounded, interspersed with an occasional ambulance and even a litter carried by mud-and-blood-encrusted medics. They are in strange and shocking contrast to Patton's shiny, polished car with its colorful banners and insignie, which overtakes them going in the same direction.

Their wounds covered with temporary blood-soaked bandages the men bearded and gaunt, bone-weary and numb with pain. Those whose eyes are bandaged are led by others. Those with leg wounds are given support by their fellows, Crude splints, improvised crutches and slings are every- where. The men stare hollow-eyes at the Patton vehicles.
His face remains hawklike and unyielding, but something in his eyes indicates the twinge of guilt and sympathy he is unwilling to reveal.
One is naked to the waist, his chest heavily bandaged. The other is hobbling along, with the aid of an improvise erutch, on a badly shattered foot. They stare up at Patton, who is passing by slowly.
There he goes -- 'old blood and guts.'
(bitterly) Yeah -- our blood and his guts.
Shooting over Patton's shoulder, with his driver at the wheel. On the road up ahead is a sign with an arrow that reads: 19TH EVACUATION HOSPITAL. Cont.
66 76 236 Cont. 239 243 Patton taps the driver on the shoulder, indicates with hi pointed finger that he is to follow the arrow, The drivar starts to turn off the road.

Patton is walking down the aisle, accompanied by a Medica Corps COLONEL, the Ward Surgeon and the ever-present Codm The patients here are all badly wounded. Some are amputze some have bandages covering their entire faces, some are - getting plasma. Patton stops by each bed with a word fo each man. We can't hear what he's saying until: Camera moves in on Patton as he stops by one of the beds, occupied by a MEXICAN-AMERICAN SOLDIER. Patton glances at the name tag on the bed,
Where'd you get it, Gomez?
(weakly) In the chest, sir.

You might be interested in this -- the last German I saw had no chest and no head either. (pats his arm) Get well quickly, son. Moving on, Patton has to pause as a mobile stretcher is pushed by. On it is a man's body, covered completely by a sheet. Patton moves on to a bed where a soldier lies pale and motionless under an oxygen mask. The man is unconscious and he is breathing heavily and with difficul His entire upper body is heavily bandaged. Patton turns to Godman with a gesture, and Codman produces a Purple Heart medal out of a briefcase he carries. Patton pins the medal onto the pillowcase of the unconscious soldier. Then he kneels beside the boy's bed, takes off his helmet and bows his head in prayer for a moment.
The Colonel, a nurse, a medical corpsman. The gesture is so corny and improbable that they each stare, even though moved, stunned and disbelieving. Is this the Patton they've heard so much about?
as Patton rises and moves on. He comes upon a young GI sitting on a bed fully clothed, wearing a helmet liner, with no sign of a dressing or a wound. Patton eyes him suspiciously. Cont.  @ 243 Cont.
What's the master with you? ‘GI I -- I guess I just can't take it, sir, The boy begins to cry.
What did you say?
Sir, it's my nerves. I can't stand the shelling anymore.
(his voice rising) Your nerves hell] You're just a goddamn coward! The soldier actually starts crying now and Patton slaps him hard across the face.

@ Shut up! I won't have e yellow bastard sit here crying in front of these brave men who've been wounded in battle. Patton strikes the man again. The man's helmet liner falls off and rolis across the floor.

{shouting now at the top of his lungs) Don't admit this yellow bastard. There's nothing the matter with him, I don't want sonsuvbitches who haven't the guts to fight stinking up this place of honor. (to soldier) You're going back to the front} You may get shot and killed, but you're going back to fight. Hither that or I'll stand you up in front of a firing squad! His right hand drops to his holster.
} I ought to shoot you myself, you VY goddamn whimpering coward! Cont. 66  78 243 Cont.1 A team of medical officers quickly takes the sobbing boy away.
{screaming) . Send him up to the front. You hear me,.e. goddamn coward! Patton suddenly realizes that everyone in the tent is staring at him.
I won't have cowards in my army!
Bradley sits in the sunlight under the makeshift awning of his trailer. Patton's command car drives up and Bradley rises to meet him. Still strained and apprehensiv Patton doesn't get out.
I had to kick some butts up there, but Truscott finally broke through to those people on the beach.
{unable to resist; evenly) You get -the casualty reports?
(his face momentarily clouding) Yeah -- I got 'em. (impatiently) What's the latest on the coast road?
The 3rd Division's east of Brolo, heading toward Messina.

66 132 B-405 Cont. 406 407 PATTON (Cont.) (noticing the glances being exchanged) Don't look so stunned, gentlemen. Plan for three possible axes of attack: from Diekirch due north; from Arlon toward Bastogne; from Neufchateau against the German left flank.

We've identified four German armies -- the Seventh, the Fifth Panzer, the Sixth SS Panzer and the Fifteenth. They've hit us with twenty-six divisions. They overran two regiments of the 106th Division, and seventy-five hundred of our men were forced to surrender...Qur ° immediate concern is that Von Runstedt has the 10lst Airborne trapped here at Bastogne --

Bastogne, by the way, is the key to this entire area. If we can hold it, we can break up the German offensive. If they take it, we're in serious trouble. (looking to de Guingand and Patton) Ike wants to know if somebody can get up there and relieve the 101st before they're cut to pieces.
I'm afraid there's nothing Field Marshal Montgomery can do -- not for some weeks at any rate.
George -- what about you? Cont.  407 Cont. There is 133
I can attack with three divisions in forty-eight hours. a stir and a shifting of chairs, surprise and skepticism on every face. They eye 66
I'd give myself some leeway if I were you.
(a little impatient) Ike wants a realistic estimate, George ... YouTre in the middle of a fight now. And it's over a hundred miles to Bastogne.
(with quiet assurance) My staff's already working out the details. him in amazement.
Frankly, I don't see how it's possible. Not in this kind of weather.
I should think first of all, you'd want to fall back and regroup.
(enjoying this) Not me, Freddy. I don't like to pay twice for the same real estate.
What about your men? You can't pull them out of the line, cart them off a hundred miles, and expect them to attack without rest!
I trained those men, Arthur. They'll do anything I tell them to do.
(drily needling) We hadn't rezlized you were so popular with your troops, General. Cont.  66 134 407 Cont.1 408 409 410
Maybe I'm not. They'll do it because they're good soldiers... And because they know, as I do, that we can still lose this war!
I think I can speak, sir, for Field Marshal Montgomery. He'd say you're demanding the impossible of your men.
(with a taunting smile) Sure he would. He doesn't realize that's what we're in business for!

There is heavy snow on the ground. Everywhere there is feverish preparation for an armored attack. A tank crew is busy slapping white paint on the side of its tank. Another tank, already whitened, is moving out fast. MED, ‘SHOT The last member of a tank crew sloshes white paint on ae helmet and mounts up as the tank pulls out.

Two tanks are parked beside the farmhouse. GIs are tossin sheets down from a second-story window to men below, who are ripping them up for camouflage suits, cutting armhole etc. One tank crew, already fitted out, mounts up and zooms off.
A Third Army armored outfit roars northward along the snow-Clogged road.

A window of this office looks out upon an arched bridge. Moving over it is a never-ending stream of Third Army tanks, half-tracks and 2-1/2 ton trucks. Bradley and Hansen are watching through the window.
If they get there in time it'll be a miracle.
(quietly) George is pretty good at miracles.  413 4 445 417- 4ig 420 421- 423 66 135

An American tank, buttoned up, advances down the street scattering cows, pigs and chickens. It is taking heavy fire from @ building. The tank rumbles up to the building pokes the muzzle of its gun through a window and blasts away, silencing the opposition.

Patton, Davenport and Codman are in @ jeep watching a mechanized outfit roll by on the snow-covered icy road. It's an impressive sight: self-propelled guns, rocket launchers, heavy equipment of all kinds and men --~ hundreds of men -- rolling forward.
Shots of the soldiers manning this equipment -- the men i the_trucks, on the self-propelled guns, in the armored personnel carriers. They are young -- but they have the look of veteran soldiers.
Patton watches as his men pass by.

Here's where the training and discipline pays off. Wkat other outfit could pull out of a winter battle, move a hundred miles, and go into a major attack with no sleep, no rest, not even hot food? (with a deep sense of pride and glory) God, I'm proud of these men.

The COLONEL commanding an armored regiment is watching fr his radio-equipped jeep as MPs sort out the traffic. Patton drives up, and the Colonel gets out of his jeep wi a piece of paper, comes over to Patton and salutes. The sound of artillery fire can be heard.
(indicating message in his hand) Sir, General McAuliffe's turned down a German surrender demand!.... You know what he said?
What?
He said, 'Nuts!'
(with a broad grin of admiration Keep moving, Colonel! A man thet eloquent has to be saved!
Heavy enemy shells are bursting all around as the GIs advance through the snow-shrouded forest. Air bursts clip the tops of huge fir trees and they come tumbling to the ground.

Sir, Von Rundstedt's thrown another panzer division against Bastogne. 101st Airborne is hanging on by their fingernails.”
Air cover -- that's what we need. Twenty-four hours of decent weather and we could make it.
{handing Patton a phone) General Mason, sir -~

(into phone) Mace -- we're short of foot soldiers. I want you to cannibalize your anti- tank units and turn them into rifle- men. Yes -- every damn one you can find! up. Davenport has.entered, snow-covered.
(grimy) General -- I just got the weather report for tomorrow. More snow.
There goes our air cover. Sir, we may have to pull up and wait for better weather.

There are brave men dying up there. I won't wait for one hour or one minute. We keep moving -- is that clear?! (after a suitable pause) We attack all night and we attack tomorrow morrming. If we are not victorious, let no one come back alive. He nods curtiy in dismissal, turns to his maps. The staff members greet this overblown statement with an exchange of uncertain glances, edge their way to the door, leaving Patton alone with Codman. Codman eyes him, decides to venture the question.
You know something, General? Sometimes they can't tell when you're acting and when you're nov. Cont.  139 435 Cont.l
(with a sly and private smile) It isn't important for them to know. Itts only important for me to know. The Third Army CHAPLAIN, a Colonel, enters, wearing a snow-flecked heavy combat jacket.

You wanted to see m, General? PaTTON Chaplain, I'm sick and tired of Third Army trying to fight Germans, the Supreme Command, no gasoline -- and now this ungodly weather!... I want a prayer. A weather prayer.
(puzzled) Weather prayer, sir?
Let's see if you can't get God working on our side in this thing.
It's going to take a pretty thick rug for that kind of praying.
I don't care if it takes a flying carpet.
Itm not sure, General, how that would be received -- a prayer for good weather so we can kill our fellowman.
I can assure you, because of my intimate relations with the Almighty, that if you write a good prayer, we'll have good weather. (curtly, glancing at his waveh) I'll expect that prayer within an hour.
{all but gulping) Yes, sir. 66  66 4.36 437 438 439 ha 140
Patton is moving through the snow and sleet of the bitter wintry night. Armored vehicles of every description are roaring past him, headed north.
He has a piece of paper in his hand. He looks up from the paper, speaks as he walks along, with great intensity.
‘Almighty and most merciful Father... we humbly beseech Thee, of Thy great goodness, to restrain these immoderate rains with which we have had to contend...!'

(o.s.) : ..-Grant us fair weather for Battle. Graciously hearken to us as soldiers who call upon Thee that...'

as the defenders rise up, scarcely able to believe what they see.

Patton is speaking into a phone, and he is beside himself with excitement.
Helio, Brad? I'm across!
Well, I'll be damned. You mean across the Rhine?
Yes! J sneaked a division over last night. Dome a favor and make the announcement, will you? I want the world to know Third Army did it before Monty could even get started!

{o.s.) Russian and American soldiers, meeting for the first time in World War II, enact a scene of wild celebration as the two allied armies meet at the Elbe River, deep inside Nazi Germany.

Jodi, literal-minded even in chaos, works feverishly to destroy classified material. Steiger is quite calmly glancing through a pile of Patton material on his desk.
(impatiently) Get a move on, Steiger. I want everything destroyed. Papers, maps, everything.

(with a grim, private smile} Everything will be destroyed, General -- that I can promise you. There is a particularly loud, close burst of artillery fire, and the point of Steiger's remark is not entirely lost on Jodi.

{as plester dust filters down) I'll never let those Russian barbarians take me! I'll die by my own hand first -- as the Fuehrer did in his bunker! His eye falls on a picture of Hitler on the wall, its frame hanging crooked from the shelling. Steiger, who seems strangely unmoved, uninvolved, is looking at a photograph of Patton he has come across.

(studying the picture with quiet objectivity) He, too, will be destroyed. The absence of war will kill hin. (thoughtfully ) The pure warrior -- a magnificent anachronism.  66 480 1s INT. HOTEL DINING ROOM ~ NIGHT ‘ (FORMERLY SCENE ),82) The room has been cleared of tables and elaborately decorated with Russian and American flags for a joint reception of high-ranking American and Russian officers. A balalaika band of Russian soldiers is playing. There are dancers and acrobats performing. Patton stands talking with Codman and Davenport as a RUSSIAN GENERAL, complete with medals, approaches with a civilian INTERPRETER. The Russian smiles affably and Patton scowls ferociously as the Interpreter speaks to him in English. A waiter appears, bearing a tray on which are two stiff drinks.
Excuse me, sir -- General Katkov wishes to know if you will join him for a drink to celebrate the German surrender. Cont.  66 146 480 Cont. 482
You tell the General I don't care to drink with him or any other Russian gonuvabitch. Both Davenport and Codman react and the Interpreter stares at him in open-mouthed disbelief.
Sir, I - I cannot tell the General thet --

(firmly) You tell him word for word -- and don't leave out the'sonuvabitch'! The Interpreter turns, red-faced and apologetic, and repe Patton's reply in Russian, The General flushes angrily, glares at Patton and for a moment an international explos seems likely, Then, controlling himself, the Russian gets off a couple of quick sentences to the Interpreter in Russian.
(to Patton) The General says he thinks you are a sonuvabitch, too.
{suddenly laughing) Okay -- I'll drink to that. One sonuvabitch to another. The two men take the glasses off the tray and drink.
