A group of CORRESPONDENTS is gathered in the office questioning Patton. Davenport and Codman are also present
General, is it true that President Roosevelt, before he died, promised you a combat command in the Pacific?
(his personal . disappointment apperent} Yes, he did. But once he was gone, there wasn't a chance. (with a wry smile) MacArthur didn't want me out there. Cont.  ®@ 66 481 Cont. 147
We've been told about these wonder - weapons the Germans were working on. Long-range rockets, push-button bombing, weapons that don't need soldiers --

(a depressed man) Wonder weapons! God, I can't see the wonder in them. Killing without heroics, Nothing is glorified, nothing is reaffirmed. No heroes, no cowards, no troops... (pause) No generals. Only those who are left alive and those who are left... dead. I'm glad I won't live to see it.
It's been pointed out, General, that you're stiil using former Nazis in key positions, despite the official de-Nazification policy.
(testily) If I'm supplied with trained personnel, I'il get rid of the Nazis. Till then, I'll use the people who know how to run the railroads and keep the telephones working.
(apparently casually) After all, General, didn't most ordinary Nazis join the party in about the same way Americans become Republicans or Democrats?
Yes. That's about it. Codman and Harkins react with instant apprehension. The Correspondents exchange glances, scribble furiously.
(baiting him) You do agree, don't you, that our national policy should be made by civilians and not by the military? Cont.
The politicians never let us finish awar. They always stop short -- leave us with another war to be fought.
(with a shrewd smile) You thinking about cur Russian allies, General? Patton smiles blandly, doesn't reply.
Sir, did you say if you found your army between the Germans and the Russians, you'd attack in both directions?
No, I didn't say that -- but I wish T had. The reporters are scribbling again. our

We reveal that an artist is working on the portrait. Patt wears his seven rows of ribbons, his four stars, his ivor handled pistols. Camera pans to Patton himself in the exact uniform and pose. But he looks different from the painting; he looks tired and worn, his hair sparser, his eyes dark, his face pale.
(entering) Sir, ‘there's a call on your line from Supreme Headquarters. General Smith. As Patton crosses and picks up the phone, Codman motions the artist out of the room.
His face is stern, his voice cuts like a lash.

Ike is furious! How could you possibly compare Democrats and épublicans to the Nazi party?... And this statement that you refuse to de-Nazify has everybody screaming -- the British, the Russians, everybody.  66 485 486 487 488 489 14g
(impatiently) The hell with those Mongoloid Russians. We let them take Berlin and Prague and God knows what else. Are we going to let them dictate policy, too?
Don't be a fool, George. The war in Europe is over. Washington dictates policy.
His personal prejudice and his burning aversion to the prospect of a peacetime existence combine to make him pre frenetic.

The war shouldn't be over! And we should stop pussyfooting about the goddamn Russians. We'll have to fight them sooner or later. Why not do it now while we have an army to do it with? Instead of disarming these German troops, we should get them to help us fight the damn Bolsheviks!
George, you'd better shup up. This line may be tapped.

I don't give a damn if it is! You want to know something, Beetle? Up till now we've been fighting the wrong people! (in a manic phase, his eyes burn with excitement) Look -- you and Ike don't have to get involved if you're so damn soft about it. Just leave it to me. In ten days I can have us at war with those sonsuvbitches and make it look like they started it.  66 490 gz 492
(genuinely frightened and appalled) You're mad, George -- you're absolutely out of your mind!

{almost frenziedly) I'm no diplomat. I'm a combat soldier -- and that's what these jokers understand. You get Ike to give me the word and I'll kick their behinds back into Russia where they belong -- |
His face grim, he quietly and deliberately hangs up.
Stunned, Patton hangs up, stares silently at Godman, who has been watching him.
Shall I call the artist back, sir?
Hell with it... Nobody wants to look at a picture of me. I'm mad, didn't you know that?

Laid out on the bed with meticulous care is Patton's elaborate blouse, with all its colorful decorations. Also the pistol belt, the shiny helmet, the riding breeches and, beside the bed, the highly polished boots. Camera pulls back to reveal Patton dressing before a mirror, He wears a pair of plain GI trousers, and Meeks is helping him into a simple Eisenhower jacket totally devoid of decorations, bearing only the four stars of his rank. As Patton studies his unfamiliar image in the mirro he seems, for the first time, to have aged. His eyes look tired and his face is pale.
(studying Patton's appearance without enthusiasm) General -- you sure you want to wear that uniform? Gont.  66 151 493 Cont.
you, 495

(deeply apprehensive, he doesn't hear) General Eisenhower's treated me very fairly -- but when he sends for me, it usually means troudile. Patton has buttoned up the unadorned jacket, and Meeks is not at all pleased with the result.
(shaking his head) That makes you look -- I don't know -- kinda naked.
You know something, George? That's the way I feel.

Featured is an impressive door (presumably in Buckingham Palace) with a liveried doorman outside it. Waiting nearb on an antique settee is Montgomery. He is in his most impressive military finery -- medals, honours, etc. -- much more elaborately dressed than we have ever seen him. The door opens and a GUARDS OFFICER, in dress uniform, steps outside, bows sligitly as he speaks to Montgomery.

Field Marshal -~ His Majesty is prepared to receive the next Commander of the Imperial General Staff. Montgomery rises and goes on into the open door, which is held for him and the Guards Officer by the doorman.

The place is decorated with elaborate flags, plaques, SHA insignia. A group of five or six CORRESPONDENTS waits impatiently in the anteroom. Several faces are recognizab as having been,at the press conference in Patton's Bad To office. Camera moves into office door, on which is a sign GENERAL EISENHOWER. The door opens and Patton comes out. His eyes are lifeless and he appears shaken, utterly drai
The Correspondents are stunned by his appearance. As he closes the door and moves off, one of them steps forward speak to him. Cont.

One moment, General -- Uncharacteristically affected by the shock Patton has sustained, two of the Correspondents take hold of their colleague and pull him back. They watch as Patton, oblivious, moves across the room like a sleepwalker and goes out.

Lined up in the room are Carver, Davenport, Bell, Codman, Stiller and several enlisted men, including Sergeant Meek and Patton's driver. Camera follows as Patton moves down the line shaking each man's hand in turn. The men try to remain at blank-faced attention, but most eyes are misty. At the end of the line, Patton turns to face the group and there are tears in his eyes.

Well, gentlemen -- all good things must come to an end -- (he continues with difficulty) The best thing that has come to me in my life is the honor and privilege of having commanded the Third Army. Good-bye -- and God bless you. He turns quickly and goes out.

It is a gray winter day, the sun blotted out by an over- cast that mutes all colors. There is snow on the ground and the streets are icy. Patton comes out of the building alone, deep in his own unhappiness, and is surprised to find himself facing Bradley, who has actually been waitin for him. Bradley now wears four stars.
I've been relieved, Brad. They've taken Third Army away from me.
I know. (he tries to sound casual) I thought we might have dinner together tonight --
(touched and grateful) That's damn thoughtful, Brad, and I appreciate it. (gesturing toward his jeep across the street) Right now I'm going to take Willy for a ee Cont.

66 153 97 Cont. 498 99 Bradley joins him as they move across the sidewalk. A man is unhitching a team of oxen from a cart parked in the street. As the oxen are removed, the cart starts rolling down the icy street. Gathering speed, it is headed straig for Patton as he steps off the curb.
George -- look out) Patton manages to leap out of the way just in time, and t cart crashes to a stop against a parked car.
as Patton gets up, brushes the snow off his uniform.
(wryly) After all I've been through, imagine me getting killed by an oxcart. Bradley grins. Patton continues moodily.
You know -- there's only one proper end for a professional soldier. A quick. death inflicted by the last bullet of the last battle. They move on across the street, camera panning with them.
They walk down the sidewalk on the opposite side of the street.
In our drive across Europe Third Army liberated twelve thousand cities and towns -- inflicted a million and a half enemy casualties.
(thoughtfully) I have a-feeling that from now on just being a good soldier won't be enough. I'm afraid we're going to have to be dislomats and administrators, too.
(growling his disgust) God help us! Cont.  66 154 499 Cont. 500 501 502 They have come to Patton's parked jeep where his driver is holding Willy. He hands the leash to Patton, who takes the dog.

George -- I just want to say one thing -- you've done a magnificent job here in Europe... I think that soldier you slapped back in Sicily did more to win the war than any other private in the Army. Overwhelmed by Bradley's generosity, Patton's face breaks into @ big, sudden grin.
See you for dinner. He turns away, leading Willy with him, and Bradley watche him go.
as Patton moves down a short side street, beyond which we can see open snow-covered countryside. An enormous windmill turns slowly. In f.g., a group of GIs is busy working, hauling supplies.
For over a thousand years, Roman conquerors returning from the wars enjoyed the honor of a triumph, a tumultuous parade.
As Patton and Willy walk together toward the ice-covered windmill, stark against the snow. Its creaking sound combined with the sound of the wind, produces a strange effect.
(o.s.) In the procession came trumpeters and musicians and strange animals from the conquered territories...
Patton's figure stands out against the otherwise absolute white snowscape. The windmill, with its eerie sound, is still in frame. Cont.  155 502 Cont.
— ( PATTON'S VOICE o.s. .., together with carts laden with treasure and captured armaments.
504 505 66 deep in thought, his eyes fixed on some middle-distance of his own.
{o.s. The conqueror rode in a triumphal chariot, the dazed prisoners walking in chains before him.

(o.s8.) . Sometimes his children, robed in white, stood with him in the chariot, or rode the trace horses...
